page.title: 12TOADSMOOR WOOD
page.content: The Toadsmoor Valley is heavily wooded with deciduous trees. Some of the woods are owned privately and some by the Forestry Commission. Beech grows best in the area. The foresters cut out ash and sycamore because they are not needed. After about fifteen years beech saplings are thinned for space and are used for firewood. They want no side branches so they cut them off or use specially selected seeds. Dead leaves and twigs are left for compost. The big trees are felled at about one hundred years and sold for furniture at about two hundred pounds each. If they grow any silver birch they don't fell them because they look nice. Although elm was not grown widely locally Dutch Elm Disease has now killed all of them. The wood has a lake called Toadsmoor Lake. It has been known to freeze over in winter.
